issues.description: Attribute type mismatch for 'lectureName': the problem statement (UML and text) specifies lectureName as a String, but the solution repository implements a custom LectureName class and uses LectureName as the field type. This diverges from the exercise specification and will confuse students about the expected type. It also creates a mismatch between the intended UML/design and the solution structure.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution consistent with the problem statement: use a String for lectureName in Lecture (change the Lecture field and constructor parameter to String and remove the extra LectureName class), or if a LectureName wrapper is intended, update the problem statement and template UML/signatures to specify LectureName and provide that class in the template. Prefer aligning the solution to use String to match the UML and student expectations.

issues.description: Method signature/type mismatch in the solution for the lectureName getter/setter: the Lecture class field is declared as LectureName but the getter returns String and the setter accepts String. These inconsistent types in the solution code will cause compilation errors and prevent students from using the provided solution as a reference.
issues.suggested_fix:
Make the getter/setter signatures and the field type consistent in the solution. Either:
- Change the Lecture field to 'private String lectureName;' and keep/getter/setter signatures using String; or
- Change getter to 'public LectureName getLectureName()' and setter to 'public void setLectureName(LectureName lectureName)' (and keep the LectureName field). If the intent was to expose a String to students, update the solution to return/accept String (for example, return lectureName.toString() or lectureName.getValue() from a String-returning getter) and ensure types compile.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML) and the exercise description specify the attribute lectureName as type String (Lecture{ -lectureName: String }). The solution implementation, however, introduces a new class LectureName and declares the lectureName attribute as type LectureName. This is a cross-artifact type/name-level divergence for the same conceptual entity (the lecture's name). Additionally, the solution's getters/setters for lectureName are inconsistent with that change (the getter/setter signatures use String while the field is LectureName), which compounds the mapping confusion. Students expecting to implement a String-typed lectureName as shown in the UML will be unable to directly map the problem/template requirements to the solution representation.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the representation of the lecture name consistent across all artifacts. Either: (A) revert the solution to use a String field for lectureName and update the constructor/getter/setter signatures to accept/return String (this aligns with the UML and template expectations), or (B) intentionally introduce LectureName as a documented abstraction in the problem statement and template (update the UML and task description to mention LectureName) and then adjust the getter/setter types in the solution to use LectureName consistently. Also fix the getter/setter implementations so their parameter and return types match the field type.
